Title: Anatomic organization of basoventral and mediodorsal visual recipient prefrontal regions in the rhesus monkey.

@InterMapRelations.Comments: B88 does not clearly state according to which map area 1 is defined. As JB76 (a standard reference for sensory cortex) is among the references (see p. 328), it is assumed that their area 1 is identical with B88-1.

B88 does not clearly state according to which map area 1 is defined. As RA63 (a standard reference for the combined area 1-2) is among the references (see p. 328) it is assumed that their area 1 is identical with B88-1.

B88 does not clearly state according to which map area SII is defined. As JB76 (a standard reference for sensory cortex) is among the references (see p. 328), it is assumed that their area SII is identical with B88-SII.

@InterMapRelations.Citation: "The delineation of borders of distinct visual cortices was made from matched sections stained for the visualization of myelin or Nissl bodies based on descriptions in recent studies (see Yeki, 1978b; Van Essen, 1979, 1985; Maunsell and Newsome, 1987, for reviews; Seltzer and Pandya, 1978; Covey et al., 1982; Maunsell and Van Essen, 1983; Desimone and Ungerleider, 1986; Colby et al., 1988). In addition, areas of dense callosal projections aided in estimating the site of the vertical meridian which lies at the anterior border of area V3 and between V1 and V2 (Zeki and Sandemann, 1976; Van Essen and Zeki, 1978; Zeki, 1978d; Newsome et al., 1986)...The delineation of other visual cortices, including areas PO, V3 ventral (or VP), and superior temporal areas MST and MT are based on architectonic descriptions provided in other studies (Covey et al., 1982; Ungerleider and Desimone, 1986; Felleman and Van Essen, 1987; Colby et al., 1988)." (p. 319)
@InterMapRelations.Comments: MTp was originally defined by UD86a.

"The caudal portion of the lateral intraparietal bank was subdivided by Seltzer and Pandya (1980, 1986) into four architectonic zones. Area IPd is situated in the depths of the intraparietal sulcus and areas POa-i, POa-e, and PG are found successively in a direction from the depth of the sulcus toward the cortical surface. Area PG occupies the superficical portion of the lateral intraparietal bank and will be referred to as sulcal area PG in this study to distinguish from area PG within the inferior parietal lobule."
@InterMapRelations.Comments: Whereas areas POa-i and POa-e are described by both SP80 and SP86, area IPd is only described by SP86.

@InterMapRelations.Citation: "The caudal portion of the lateral intraparietal bank was subdivided by Seltzer and Pandya (1980, 1986) into four architectonic zones. Area PG occupies the superficical portion of the lateral intraparietal bank and will be referred to as sulcal area PG in this study to distinguish from area PG within the inferior parietal lobule."
@InterMapRelations.Comments: Whereas areas POa-i and POa-e are described by both SP80 and SP86, area IPd is only described by SP86.

@InterMapRelations.Citation: "The caudal portion of the lateral intraparietal bank was subdivided by Seltzer and Pandya (1980, 1986) into four architectonic zones. Area IPd is situated in the depths of the intraparietal sulcus and areas POa-i, POa-e, and PG are found successively in a direction from the depth of the sulcus toward the cortical surface. Area PG occupies the superficical portion of the lateral intraparietal bank and will be referred to as sulcal area PG in this study to distinguish from area PG within the inferior parietal lobule."
@InterMapRelations.Comments: SP80 and SP86 use different concepts of area PG: whereas SP80-PG is identical with BB47-PG, SP86-PG refers to PS82-PG which is a subarea of BB47-PG.  It is therefore safe to deduce that B88-PGlat is a subarea of the bigger SP80-PG, whereas its relation to SP86-PG is unclear."

"The caudal portion of the lateral intraparietal bank was subdivided by Seltzer and Pandya (1980, 1986) into four architectonic zones. Area IPd is situated in the depths of the intraparietal sulcus and areas POa-i, POa-e, and PG are found successively in a direction from the depth of the sulcus toward the cortical surface. Area PG occupies the superficical portion of the lateral intraparietal bank and will be referred to as sulcal area PG in this study to distinguish from area PG within the inferior parietal lobule."
@InterMapRelations_clean.Comments: Whereas areas POa-i and POa-e are described by both SP80 and SP86, area IPd is only described by SP86.

@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Citation: Information on laminar patterns: "Labeled neurons were located in cortical layers III, V, and VI. The laminar origin of corticocortical projections was correlated with the architectonic differentiation of the regions giving rise to the projecting afferent fibers. Thus, prefrontally directed projections from limbic cortices, which show a rudimentary laminar organization, emanated mainly from deep layers V and VI... On the other hand, projections from increasingly more differentiated cortices arose progressively from the upper (or supragranular) layers...This pattern was observed for projections originating in visual, auditory, somatosensory, premotor, and prefrontal cortices...The laminar origin of labeled neurons in two additional cortical zones...will be considered in more detail here. These include the caudal portion of the lateral bank of the intraparietal sulcus and the medial bankl of the superior temporal sulcus. Most labeled neurons in the lateral intraparietal bank were found in layer III. However, relatively more labeled neurons were found in layers V and VI in the superficial portion of the sulcus (areas PG and POa-e) when compared with the deep portions of the sulcus (areas IPd and POa-i) (Fig. 13A). The laminar origin of labeled neurons within the medial bank of the superior temporal sulcus is shown in Figure 13B. Most labeled neurons in this region were found in layer III as well...area TPO, situated in the upper portion of the bank, had a somewhat higher percentage of its labeled neurons in the deep layers compared to areas PGa and IPa, which are located progressively in deeper portions of the medial superior temporal bank and the adjacent floor of the sulcus." (pp. 333, 337)
@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Comments: %-values of labelled neurons for the paired areas MST/MTp, V4t/V4, paI/proA, TS2/paAr and values <0.1% (indicated by asterisks) in tables 2-9 were not considered.
